title: Vitamin C - Wikipedia
author: Authority control National France BnF data Israel United States Japan Czech Republic
cleaned_text: Vitamin [ascorbic acid](/wiki/Chemistry_of_ascorbic_acid) and ascorbate) is a water-soluble [vitamin](/wiki/Vitamin) found in citrus and other fruits and vegetables, also sold as a [dietary supplement](/wiki/Dietary_supplement) [[9]](#cite_note-AHFS2016-9) and as a [topical](/wiki/Topical_medication) "serum" ingredient to treat [melasma](/wiki/Melasma) (dark pigment spots) and wrinkles on the face. [[10]](#cite_note-Harvard2021-10) It is used to prevent and treat [scurvy](/wiki/Scurvy). [[9]](#cite_note-AHFS2016-9) Vitamin C is an [essential nutrient](/wiki/Nutrient#Essential_nutrients) involved in the repair of [tissue](/wiki/Tissue_(biology)), the formation of [collagen](/wiki/Collagen), and the [enzymatic](/wiki/Enzyme) production of certain [neurotransmitters](/wiki/Neurotransmitter). [[9]](#cite_note-AHFS2016-9) [[11]](#cite_note-DRItext-11) It is required for the functioning of several enzymes and is important for [immune system](/wiki/Immune_system) function. [[11]](#cite_note-DRItext-11) [[12]](#cite_note-lpi2018-12) It also functions as an [antioxidant](/wiki/Antioxidant). [[13]](#cite_note-NIH2016-13) Most animals are able to [synthesize their own vitamin C](#Synthesis). However, [apes](/wiki/Ape) (including humans) and monkeys (but not all [primates](/wiki/Primates)), most [bats](/wiki/Bat), some rodents, and certain other animals must acquire it from dietary sources. There is some evidence that regular use of supplements may reduce the duration of the [common cold](/wiki/Common_cold), but it does not appear to prevent infection. [[13]](#cite_note-NIH2016-13) [[14]](#cite_note-WHO2008-14) [[15]](#cite_note-Hem2013-15) It is unclear whether supplementation [cancer](/wiki/Cancer), [cardiovascular disease](/wiki/Cardiovascular_disease), or [dementia](/wiki/Dementia). [[16]](#cite_note-Ye2013-16) [[17]](#cite_note-17) It may be taken by mouth or by injection. [[9]](#cite_note-AHFS2016-9) Vitamin C is generally well tolerated. [[9]](#cite_note-AHFS2016-9) Large doses may cause gastrointestinal discomfort, headache, trouble sleeping, and flushing of the skin. [[9]](#cite_note-AHFS2016-9) [[14]](#cite_note-WHO2008-14) Normal doses are safe during [pregnancy](/wiki/Pregnancy). [[8]](#cite_note-Drugscom_pregnancy-8) The United States [Institute of Medicine](/wiki/National_Academy_of_Medicine) recommends against taking large doses. [[11]](#cite_note-DRItext-11) Vitamin C was discovered in 1912, isolated in 1928, and in 1933, the first vitamin to be [chemically produced](/wiki/Chemical_synthesis). [[18]](#cite_note-Squires-18) It is on the [World Health Organization's List of Essential Medicines](/wiki/WHO_Model_List_of_Essential_Medicines). [[19]](#cite_note-WHO21st-19) [[20]](#cite_note-WHO22nd-20) Vitamin C is available as an inexpensive [generic](/wiki/Generic_drug) and [over-the-counter](/wiki/Over-the-counter_drug) medication. [[9]](#cite_note-AHFS2016-9) [[21]](#cite_note-BNF76-21) Partly for its discovery, [Albert Szent-Györgyi](/wiki/Albert_Szent-Gy%C3%B6rgyi) [Walter Haworth](/wiki/Norman_Haworth) were awarded and Medicine](/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physiology_and_Medicine) and [Chemistry](/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Chemistry), storage or cooking may reduce vitamin C content in foods. [[13]](#cite_note-NIH2016-13) Definition[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C&action=edit§ion=1)] Vitamin C is an essential [nutrient](/wiki/Nutrient) for certain animals including humans. The term vitamin C encompasses several [vitamers](/wiki/Vitamer) that have vitamin C activity in animals. Ascorbate salts such as sodium ascorbate and calcium ascorbate are used in some dietary supplements. These release ascorbate upon digestion. Ascorbate and ascorbic acid are both naturally present in the body, since the forms interconvert according to [pH](/wiki/PH). Oxidized forms of the molecule such as [dehydroascorbic acid](/wiki/Dehydroascorbic_acid) are converted back to ascorbic acid by reducing agents. [[11]](#cite_note-DRItext-11) [[24]](#cite_note-PKIN2020VitC-24) Vitamin C functions as a [cofactor](/wiki/Cofactor_(biochemistry)) in many [enzymatic](/wiki/Enzyme) reactions in animals (including humans) that mediate a variety of essential biological functions, including [wound healing](/wiki/Wound_healing) and [collagen](/wiki/Collagen) synthesis. In humans, vitamin C deficiency leads to impaired collagen synthesis, contributing to the more severe symptoms of [scurvy](/wiki/Scurvy). [[11]](#cite_note-DRItext-11) Another biochemical role of vitamin C is to act as an [antioxidant](/wiki/Antioxidant) (a [reducing agent](/wiki/Reducing_agent)) by donating electrons to various enzymatic and non-enzymatic reactions. [[11]](#cite_note-DRItext-11) Doing so converts vitamin C to an oxidized state - either as semidehydroascorbic acid or dehydroascorbic acid. These compounds can be restored to a reduced state by [glutathione](/wiki/Glutathione) and [NADPH](/wiki/NADPH)-dependent enzymatic mechanisms. [[25]](#cite_note-pmid8144521-25) [[26]](#cite_note-isbn1-4377-0959-1-26) [[27]](#cite_note-Gropper_2005-27) [substrate](/wiki/Substrate_(chemistry)) for [ascorbate peroxidase](/wiki/Ascorbate_peroxidase). This enzyme utilizes ascorbate to neutralize excess hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) by converting it to water (H2O) and oxygen. [[12]](#cite_note-lpi2018-12) [[24]](#cite_note-PKIN2020VitC-24) [[28]](#cite_note-28) Deficiency[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C&action=edit§ion=2)] Vitamin C blood [serum](/wiki/Serum_(blood)) levels are considered saturated at levels > 65 mol/L (1.1 mg/dL), achieved by consuming amounts which are at, or above, the [Recommended Dietary Allowance](/wiki/Recommended_Dietary_Allowance), while adequate levels are defined as 50 mol/L. [Hypovitaminosis](/wiki/Hypovitaminosis) of vitamin C is defined as 23 mol/L and [deficiency](/wiki/Vitamin_deficiency) occurs at 11.4 mol/L. [[29]](#cite_note-Carr2016-29) [[30]](#cite_note-Schleicher2009-30) For those 20 years of age or above, data from the U.S. 2003-04 [National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey](/wiki/National_Health_and_Nutrition_Examination_Survey) showed mean and median serum concentrations of 49.0 and 54.4 mol/L, respectively. The percent of people reported as deficient was 7.1%. [[30]](#cite_note-Schleicher2009-30) [Scurvy](/wiki/Scurvy) is a disease resulting from a deficiency of vitamin C. Without this vitamin, [collagen](/wiki/Collagen) made by the body is too unstable to perform its function and several other [enzymes](/wiki/Enzyme) in the body do not operate correctly. [[12]](#cite_note-lpi2018-12) Scurvy is characterized by [spots](/wiki/Hyperkeratosis) on and [bleeding](/wiki/Ecchymosis) under the skin, spongy gums, 'corkscrew' hair growth, and poor wound healing. The skin lesions are most abundant on the thighs and legs, and a person with the ailment looks pale, feels depressed, and is partially immobilized. In advanced scurvy there are open, [suppurating wounds](/wiki/Suppuration), loss of [teeth](/wiki/Tooth), [bone abnormalities](/wiki/Bone) and, eventually, death. [[31]](#cite_note-31) Notable human dietary studies of experimentally induced scurvy were conducted on [conscientious objectors](/wiki/Conscientious_objector) during World War II in Britain and on Iowa state prisoners in the late 1960s to the 1980s. Men in the prison study developed the first signs of scurvy about four weeks after starting the vitamin C-free diet, whereas in the earlier British study, six to eight months were required, possibly due to the pre-loading of this group with a 70 mg/day supplement for six weeks before the scorbutic diet was fed. Men in both studies had blood levels of ascorbic acid too low to be accurately measured by the time they developed signs of scurvy. These studies both reported that all obvious symptoms of scurvy could be completely reversed by supplementation of only 10 mg a day. [[32]](#cite_note-pmid4977512-32) [[33]](#cite_note-pmid16510534-33) People in [sepsis](/wiki/Sepsis) or [septic shock](/wiki/Septic_shock) may have micronutrient deficiencies, including low levels of vitamin C. [[34]](#cite_note-34) Medical uses[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C&action=edit§ion=3)] Vitamin C has a definitive role in treating scurvy, which is a disease caused by vitamin C deficiency. Beyond that, a role for vitamin C as prevention or treatment for various diseases is disputed, with reviews reporting conflicting results. A 2012 [Cochrane](/wiki/Cochrane_(organisation)) review reported no effect of vitamin C supplementation on overall mortality. [[35]](#cite_note-35) It is on the [World Organization's List Medicines](/wiki/WHO_Model_List_of_Essential_Medicines). [[19]](#cite_note-WHO21st-19) [[20]](#cite_note-WHO22nd-20) Scurvy[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C&action=edit§ion=4)] The disease [scurvy](/wiki/Scurvy) is caused by vitamin C deficiency and can be prevented and treated with vitamin C-containing foods or dietary supplements. [[9]](#cite_note-AHFS2016-9) [[11]](#cite_note-DRItext-11) It takes at least a month of little to no vitamin C before symptoms occur. [[32]](#cite_note-pmid4977512-32) Early symptoms are malaise and lethargy, progressing to shortness of breath, bone pain, bleeding gums, susceptibility to bruising, poor wound healing, and finally fever, convulsions and eventual death. [[9]](#cite_note-AHFS2016-9) Until quite late in the disease the damage is reversible, as healthy collagen replaces the defective collagen with vitamin C repletion. Treatment can be oral supplementation of the vitamin or by intramuscular or intravenous injection. [[9]](#cite_note-AHFS2016-9) Scurvy was known to [Hippocrates](/wiki/Hippocrates) in the classical era. [[36]](#cite_note-36) The disease was shown to be prevented by citrus fruits in an early controlled trial by a [Royal Navy](/wiki/Royal_Navy) surgeon, [James Lind](/wiki/James_Lind), in 1747, on board HMS Salisbury. [[37]](#cite_note-Baron2009-37) From 1796 onward, lemon juice was issued to all Royal Navy crewmen. [[38]](#cite_note-lind_james-38) [[37]](#cite_note-Baron2009-37) Common cold[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C&action=edit§ion=5)] Research on vitamin C in the common cold has been divided into effects on prevention, duration, and severity. A [Cochrane review](/wiki/Cochrane_(organisation)) which looked at at least 200 mg/day concluded that vitamin C taken on a regular basis was not effective in prevention of the common cold. Restricting analysis to trials that used at least 1000 mg/day also saw no prevention benefit. However, taking vitamin C on a regular basis did reduce the average duration by 8% in adults and 14% in children, and also reduced severity of colds. [[15]](#cite_note-Hem2013-15) A subset of trials in adults reported that supplementation reduced the incidence of colds by half in marathon runners, skiers, or soldiers in subarctic conditions. [[15]](#cite_note-Hem2013-15) Another subset of trials looked at therapeutic use, meaning that vitamin C was not started unless the people started to feel the beginnings of a cold. In these, vitamin C did not affect duration or severity. [[15]](#cite_note-Hem2013-15) An earlier review stated that vitamin C did not prevent colds, did reduce duration, did not reduce severity. [[39]](#cite_note-Heimer_2009-39) The authors of the Cochrane review concluded that: The failure of vitamin C supplementation to reduce the incidence of colds in the general population indicates that routine vitamin C supplementation is not justified ... Regular supplementation trials have shown that vitamin C reduces the duration of colds, but this was not replicated in the few therapeutic trials that have been carried out. Nevertheless, given the consistent effect of vitamin C on the duration and severity of colds in the regular supplementation studies, and the low cost and safety, it may be worthwhile for common cold patients to test on an individual basis whether therapeutic vitamin C is beneficial for them." [[15]] Vitamin C distributes readily in high concentrations into [immune cells](/wiki/Immune_system), has [antimicrobial](/wiki/Antimicrobial) and [natural killer cell](/wiki/Natural_killer_cell) activities, promotes [lymphocyte](/wiki/Lymphocyte) proliferation, and is consumed quickly during infections, effects suggesting a prominent role in immune system regulation. [[40]](#cite_note-:2-40) The [European Food Safety Authority](/wiki/European_Food_Safety_Authority) found a [cause and effect relationship](/wiki/Causality) exists between the dietary intake of vitamin C and functioning of a normal immune system in adults and in children under three years of age. [[41]](#cite_note-efsa09-41) [[42]](#cite_note-efsa15-42) Several studies found Vitamin C to have specific antiviral effects in which it inactivates the RNA or DNA of viruses or in the assembly of the virus. [[43]](#cite_note-43) [[44]](#cite_note-44) [[45]](#cite_note-45) COVID-19[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C&action=edit§ion=6)] According to [ClinicalTrials.gov](/wiki/ClinicalTrials.gov), as of early 2021 there were 50 completed or ongoing COVID-19 clinical trials including vitamin C as a treatment. [[46]](#cite_note-46) A meta-analysis of six published trials was published in October 2021. Treatments were either oral or intravenous. Dose ranged from 50 mg/kg/day to 24 g/day. Reported outcomes were mortality, hospitalization duration, intensive care duration and need for ventilation. From the Conclusion: "The present meta-analysis showed that administration of vitamin C did not have any effect on major health outcomes in COVID infected patients, in comparison to either placebo/standard therapy. Sub-group analysis also revealed that irrespective of its dosage, route of administration and disease severity, it did not have discernible benefit in such patients. Hence, larger prospective randomized trials are needed in order to evaluate the effect of isolated vitamin C administration, separately for both vitamin C replete and deplete individuals." [[47]](#cite_note-pmid34739908-47) During March through July 2020, vitamin C was the subject of more US FDA warning letters than any other ingredient for prevention and/or treatment of COVID-19. [[48]](#cite_note-48) As of April 2021, the [National Institutes of Health](/wiki/National_Institutes_of_Health) (NIH) COVID-19 Treatment Guidelines stated that "there are insufficient data to recommend either for or against the use of vitamin C for the prevention or treatment of COVID-19." [[49]](#cite_note-49) Cancer[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C&action=edit§ion=7)] There is no evidence that vitamin C supplementation reduces the risk of lung cancer in healthy people or those at high risk due to smoking or asbestos exposure. [[50]](#cite_note-50) A second meta-analysis found no effect on the risk of prostate cancer. [[51]](#cite_note-Stratton_J,_Godwin_M_243-52-51) Two meta-analyses evaluated the effect of vitamin C supplementation on the risk of colorectal cancer. One found a weak association between vitamin C consumption and reduced risk, and the other found no effect from supplementation. [[52]](#cite_note-52) [[53]](#cite_note-53) A 2011 meta-analysis failed to find support for the prevention of breast cancer with vitamin C supplementation, [[54]](#cite_note-54) but a second study concluded that vitamin C may be associated with increased survival in those already diagnosed. [[55]](#cite_note-55) A 2015 meta-analysis showed no antitumor effect nor improvement in quality-of-life measures from high-dose vitamin C. This review included trials of oral and intravenous vitamin C. [[56]](#cite_note-Jacobs2015-56) Cardiovascular disease[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C&action=edit§ion=8)] In 2017, an independent study evaluating 15,445 participants found no evidence to show vitamin C decreases the risk cardiovascular disease. [[57]](#cite_note-57) These results supported one 2013 review which found no evidence that antioxidant vitamin supplementation reduces the risk of [myocardial infarction](/wiki/Myocardial_infarction), [stroke](/wiki/Stroke), cardiovascular mortality, or all-cause mortality (it did not provide subset analysis for trials that just used vitamin C). [[16]](#cite_note-Ye2013-16) However, another 2013 review found an association between higher circulating vitamin C levels or dietary vitamin C and a lower risk of stroke. [[58]](#cite_note-58) A 2014 review found a positive effect of vitamin C on [endothelial dysfunction](/wiki/Endothelial_dysfunction) when taken at doses greater than 500 mg per day. The endothelium is a layer of cells that line the interior surface of blood vessels. [[59]](#cite_note-59) Brain function[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C&action=edit§ion=9)] A 2017 systematic review found lower vitamin C concentrations in people with cognitive impairment, including [Alzheimer's disease](/wiki/Alzheimer%27s_disease) and [dementia](/wiki/Dementia), compared to people with normal cognition. [[60]](#cite_note-travica-60) The cognitive testing, however, relied on the [Mini-Mental State Examination](/wiki/Mini-Mental_State_Examination), which is only a general test of cognition, indicating an overall low quality of research assessing the potential importance of vitamin C on cognition in normal and impaired people. [[60]](#cite_note-travica-60) A review of nutrient status in people with Alzheimer's disease reported low plasma vitamin C, but also low blood levels of [folate](/wiki/Folate), [vitamin B12](/wiki/Vitamin_B12), and [vitamin E](/wiki/Vitamin_E). the causes of [iron-deficiency anemia](/wiki/Iron-deficiency_anemia) is reduced absorption of iron. Iron absorption can be enhanced though ingestion of vitamin C alongside iron-containing food or supplements. The instability of vitamin C during cooking and/or storage limits the number of foods suitable for this. Vitamin C helps to keep iron in the reduced ferrous state, which is more soluble and more easily absorbed. [[62]](#cite_note-62) Other diseases[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C&action=edit§ion=11)] Studies examining the effects of vitamin C intake on the risk of [Alzheimer's disease](/wiki/Alzheimer%27s_disease) have reached conflicting conclusions. [[63]](#cite_note-63) [[64]](#cite_note-64) Maintaining a healthy dietary intake is probably more important than supplementation for achieving any potential benefit. [[65]](#cite_note-65) A 2010 review found no role for vitamin C supplementation in the treatment of [rheumatoid arthritis](/wiki/Rheumatoid_arthritis). [[66]](#cite_note-66) Vitamin C supplementation does not prevent or slow the progression of age-related [cataract](/wiki/Cataract). [[67]](#cite_note-67) A systematic review reported that low intake and low serum concentration was associated with greater progression of periodontal disease. [[68]](#cite_note-68) Vitamin C is marketed as a topical "serum" ingredient to prevent or treat skin aging, melasma (dark pigment spots) and wrinkles on the face. The purported mechanism is that it functions as an antioxidant, neutralizing [free radicals](/wiki/Free-radical_theory_of_aging) from sunlight exposure, air pollutants or normal metabolic processes. [[10]](#cite_note-Harvard2021-10) Side effects[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C&action=edit§ion=12)] Vitamin C is a water-soluble vitamin, [[69]](#cite_note-Medline-69) with dietary excesses not absorbed, and excesses in the blood rapidly excreted in the urine, so it exhibits remarkably low acute toxicity. [[12]](#cite_note-lpi2018-12) More than two to three grams may cause indigestion, particularly when taken on an empty stomach. However, taking vitamin C in the form of [sodium ascorbate](/wiki/Sodium_ascorbate) and calcium ascorbate may minimize this effect. [[70]](#cite_note-Pauling1976-70) Other symptoms reported for large doses include nausea, abdominal cramps and diarrhea. These effects are attributed to the osmotic effect of unabsorbed vitamin C passing through the intestine. [[11]](#cite_note-DRItext-11) In theory, high vitamin C intake may cause excessive absorption of iron. A summary of reviews of supplementation in healthy subjects did not report this problem, but left as untested the possibility that individuals with hereditary [hemochromatosis](/wiki/Hemochromatosis) might be adversely affected. [[11]](#cite_note-DRItext-11) There is a longstanding belief among the mainstream medical community that vitamin C increases risk of [kidney stones](/wiki/Kidney_stone). [[71]](#cite_note-BattlingQuackery-71) "Reports of kidney stone formation associated with excess ascorbic acid intake are limited to individuals with renal disease". [[11]](#cite_note-DRItext-11) Reviews state that "data from epidemiological studies do not support an association between excess ascorbic acid intake and kidney stone formation in apparently healthy individuals", [[11]](#cite_note-DRItext-11) [[72]](#cite_note-VCreview2003-72) although one large, multi-year trial did report a nearly two-fold increase in kidney stones in men who regularly consumed a vitamin C supplement. [[73]](#cite_note-73) Diet[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C&action=edit§ion=13)] Recommended levels[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C&action=edit§ion=14)] Recommendations for vitamin C intake by adults have been set by various national agencies: - 40 milligrams per day: India [National Institute of Nutrition, Hyderabad](/wiki/National_Institute_of_Nutrition,_Hyderabad) [[74]](#cite_note-NIN-74) - 45 milligrams per day or 300 milligrams week: the [World Commission](/wiki/European_Commission)Council on nutrition labeling [[76]](#cite_note-EU_RDA-76) - 90 mg/day (males) and 75 mg/day (females): Health Canada 2007 [[77]](#cite_note-urlNatural_Health_Product_Monograph_-_Vitamin_C_[Health_Canada,_2007]-77) - 90 mg/day (males) and 75 mg/day (females): [United States National Academy of Sciences](/wiki/United_States_National_Academy_of_Sciences). [[11]](#cite_note-DRItext-11) - 100 milligrams per day: Japan National Institute of Health and Nutrition. [[78]](#cite_note-JapanDRI2015-78) - 110 mg/day (males) and 95 mg/day (females): [European Food Safety Authority](/wiki/European_Food_Safety_Authority) [[79]](#cite_note-EFSA-Recommended-79) |US vitamin C recommendations (| In 2000, the chapter on Vitamin C in the North American [Dietary Reference Intake](/wiki/Dietary_Reference_Intake) was updated to give the [Recommended Dietary Allowance](/wiki/Recommended_Dietary_Allowance) (RDA) as 90 milligrams per day for adult men, 75 mg/day for adult women, and setting a [Tolerable upper intake level](/wiki/Tolerable_upper_intake_level) (UL) for adults of 2,000 mg/day. [[11]](#cite_note-DRItext-11) The table (right) shows RDAs for the United States and Canada for children, and for pregnant and lactating women, [[11]](#cite_note-DRItext-11) as well as the ULs for adults. For the European Union, the EFSA set higher recommendations for adults, and also for children: 20 mg/day for ages 1-3, 30 mg/day for ages 4-6, 45 mg/day for ages 7-10, 70 mg/day for ages 11-14, 100 mg/day for males ages 15-17, 90 mg/day for females ages 15-17. For pregnancy 100 mg/day; for lactation 155 mg/day. [[79]](#cite_note-EFSA-Recommended-79) India, on the other hand, has set recommendations much lower: 40 mg/day for ages 1 through adult, 60 mg/day for pregnancy, and 80 mg/day for lactation. [[74]](#cite_note-NIN-74) Clearly, there is not consensus among countries. Cigarette smokers and people exposed to secondhand smoke have lower serum vitamin C levels than nonsmokers. [[30]](#cite_note-Schleicher2009-30) The thinking is that inhalation of smoke causes oxidative damage, depleting this antioxidant vitamin. [[11]](#cite_note-DRItext-11) The U.S. Institute of Medicine estimated that smokers need 35 mg more vitamin C per day than nonsmokers, but did not formally establish a higher RDA for smokers. [[11]](#cite_note-DRItext-11) One meta-analysis showed an inverse relationship between vitamin C intake and lung cancer, although it concluded that more research is needed to confirm this observation. [[80]](#cite_note-80) The U.S. National Center for Health Statistics conducts biannual National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) to assess the health and nutritional status of adults and children in the United States. Some results are reported as What We Eat In America. The 2013-2014 survey reported that for adults ages 20 years and older, men consumed on average 83.3 mg/d and women 75.1 mg/d. This means that half the women and more than half the men are not consuming the RDA for vitamin C. [[81]](#cite_note-81) The same survey stated that about 30% of adults reported they consumed a vitamin C dietary supplement or a multi-vitamin/mineral supplement that included vitamin C, and that for these people total consumption was between 300 and 400 mg/d. [[82]](#cite_note-82) Tolerable upper intake level[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C&action=edit§ion=15)] In 2000, the Institute of Medicine of the U.S. National Academy of Sciences set a [Tolerable upper intake level](/wiki/Tolerable_upper_intake_level) (UL) for adults of 2,000 mg/day. The amount was chosen because human trials had reported diarrhea and other gastrointestinal disturbances at intakes of greater than 3,000 mg/day. This was the Lowest-Observed-Adverse-Effect Level (LOAEL), meaning that other adverse effects were observed at even higher intakes. ULs are progressively lower for younger and younger children. [[11]](#cite_note-DRItext-11) In 2006, the [European Food Safety Authority](/wiki/European_Food_Safety_Authority) (EFSA) also pointed out the disturbances at that dose level, but reached the conclusion that there was not sufficient evidence to set a UL for vitamin C, [[83]](#cite_note-83) as did the Japan National Institute of Health and Nutrition in 2010. [[78]](#cite_note-JapanDRI2015-78) Food labeling[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C&action=edit§ion=16)] For U.S. food and dietary supplement labeling purposes, the amount in a serving is expressed as a percent of Daily Value (%DV). For vitamin C labeling purposes, 100% of the Daily Value was 60 mg, but as of May 27, 2016, it was revised to 90 mg to bring it into agreement with the RDA. [[84]](#cite_note-FedReg-84) [[85]](#cite_note-85) A table of the old and new adult daily values is provided at [Reference Daily Intake](/wiki/Reference_Daily_Intake). European Union regulations require that labels declare energy, protein, fat, saturated fat, carbohydrates, sugars, and salt. Voluntary nutrients may be shown if present in significant amounts. Instead of Daily Values, amounts are shown as percent of Reference Intakes (RIs). For vitamin C, 100% RI was set at 80 mg in 2011. [[86]](#cite_note-86) Sources[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C&action=edit§ion=17)] Although also present in other foods, the richest natural sources of vitamin C are fruits and vegetables. [[12]](#cite_note-lpi2018-12) The vitamin is the most widely taken [dietary supplement](/wiki/Dietary_supplement). [[12]](#cite_note-lpi2018-12) Plant sources[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C&action=edit§ion=18)] While plant foods are generally a good source of vitamin C, the amount in foods of plant origin depends on the variety of the plant, soil condition, climate where it grew, length of time since it was picked, storage conditions, and method of preparation. [[87]](#cite_note-Duarte2010-87) [[88]](#cite_note-88) Organically farmed citrus may have a higher vitamin C content than conventionally farmed. [[87]](#cite_note-Duarte2010-87) The following table is approximate and shows the relative abundance in different raw plant sources. [[89]](#cite_note-89) [[90]](#cite_note-natural-vit-c-90) Generally, cooking reduces the amount of vitamin C. As some plants were analyzed fresh while others were dried (thus, artificially increasing concentration of individual constituents such as vitamin C), the data are subject to potential variation and difficulties for comparison. The amount is given in milligrams per 100 grams of the edible portion of the fruit or vegetable: |Raw plant source plant sources, animal-sourced foods do not provide so great an amount of vitamin C, and what there is, is largely destroyed by the heat used when it is cooked. For example, raw chicken liver contains 17.9 mg/100 g, but fried, the content is reduced to 2.7 mg/100 g. Smoked products, such as beef sticks, [[98]](#cite_note-98) retain some vitamin C however. Vitamin C is present in [human breast milk](/wiki/Breastfeeding#Benefits) at 5.0 mg/100 g. One tested sample of infant formula contained 6.1 mg/100 g. Cow's milk contains only 1.0 mg/ 100 g, but the heat of pasteurization destroys it. [[99]](#cite_note-99) Goat's milk contains 1.3mg/100 g, [[100]](#cite_note-100) unless pasteurized. Chicken eggs contain no vitamin C, whether raw or cooked. [[91]](#cite_note-USDA-NDL-91) Food preparation[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C&action=edit§ion=20)] Vitamin C [chemically decomposes](/wiki/Chemical_decomposition) under certain conditions, many of which may occur during the cooking of food. Vitamin C concentrations in various food substances decrease with time in proportion to the temperature at which they are stored. [[101]](#cite_note-pmid7621082-101) Cooking can reduce the vitamin C content of vegetables by around 60%, possibly due to increased enzymatic destruction. [[102]](#cite_note-pmid14801407-102) Longer cooking times may add to this effect. [[103]](#cite_note-Oxford-103) Another cause of vitamin C loss from food is [leaching](/wiki/Leaching_(chemical_science)), which transfers vitamin C to the cooking water, which is decanted and not consumed. [Broccoli](/wiki/Broccoli) may retain vitamin C during cooking or storage more than most vegetables. [[104]](#cite_note-Combs-104) Supplements[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C&action=edit§ion=21)] Vitamin C dietary supplements are available as tablets, capsules, drink mix packets, in multi-vitamin/mineral formulations, in antioxidant formulations, and as crystalline powder. [[9]](#cite_note-AHFS2016-9) Vitamin C is also added to some fruit juices and juice drinks. Tablet and capsule content ranges from 25 mg to 1500 mg per serving. The most commonly used supplement compounds are ascorbic acid, sodium ascorbate and calcium ascorbate. [[9]](#cite_note-AHFS2016-9) Vitamin C molecules can also be bound to the fatty acid palmitate, creating [ascorbyl palmitate](/wiki/Ascorbyl_palmitate), or else incorporated [[105]](#cite_note-105) fortification[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C&action=edit§ion=22)] In 2014, the [Canadian Food Inspection Agency](/wiki/Canadian_Food_Inspection_Agency) evaluated the effect of fortification of foods with ascorbate in the guidance document, Foods to Which Vitamins, Mineral Nutrients and Amino Acids May or Must be Added. [[106]](#cite_note-Can14-106) Voluntary and mandatory fortification was described for various classes of foods. Among foods classified for mandatory fortification with vitamin C were fruit-flavored drinks, mixes, and concentrates, foods for a low-energy diet, replacement](/wiki/Meal_replacement) products, and [evaporated milk](/wiki/Evaporated_milk). [[106]](#cite_note-Can14-106) acid and some of its [salts](/wiki/Salt_(chemistry)) and [esters](/wiki/Ester) are common [additives](/wiki/Food_additive) added to various foods, such as [canned](/wiki/Canning) fruits, mostly to slow [oxidation](/wiki/Redox) and [enzymatic browning](/wiki/Food_browning). [[107]](#cite_note-107) It may be used as a [flour treatment agent](/wiki/Flour_treatment_agent) used in [breadmaking](/wiki/Breadmaking). [[108]](#cite_note-fobvc-108) As food additives, they are assigned [E numbers](/wiki/E_number), with safety assessment and approval the responsibility of the [European Food Safety Authority](/wiki/European_Food_Safety_Authority). [[109]](#cite_note-109) The relevant E numbers are: - E300 ascorbic acid (approved for use as a food additive in the UK, [[110]](#cite_note-food.gov.uk-110)U.S. [[111]](#cite_note-fda.gov-111)Canada, [[112]](#cite_note-health.canada.ca-112)Australia and New Zealand [[113]](#cite_note-comlaw.gov.au-113)) - E301 [sodium ascorbate](/wiki/Sodium_ascorbate)(approved for use as a food additive in the UK, [[110]](#cite_note-food.gov.uk-110)U.S., [[114]](#cite_note-114)Canada, [[112]](#cite_note-health.canada.ca-112)Australia and New Zealand [[113]](#cite_note-comlaw.gov.au-113)) - E302 [calcium ascorbate](/wiki/Calcium_ascorbate)(approved for use as a food additive in the UK, [[110]](#cite_note-food.gov.uk-110)U.S. [[111]](#cite_note-fda.gov-111)Canada, [[112]](#cite_note-health.canada.ca-112)Australia and New Zealand [[113]](#cite_note-comlaw.gov.au-113)) - E303 [potassium ascorbate](/wiki/Potassium_ascorbate)(approved in Australia and New Zealand, [[113]](#cite_note-comlaw.gov.au-113)but not in the UK, U.S. or Canada) - E304 fatty acid esters of ascorbic acid such as [ascorbyl palmitate](/wiki/Ascorbyl_palmitate)(approved for use as a food additive in the UK, [[110]](#cite_note-food.gov.uk-110)U.S., [[111]](#cite_note-fda.gov-111)Canada, [[112]](#cite_note-health.canada.ca-112)Australia and New Zealand [[113]](#cite_note-comlaw.gov.au-113)) The stereoisomers of Vitamin C have a similar effect in food despite their lack of efficacy in humans. They include [erythorbic acid](/wiki/Erythorbic_acid) and [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C&action=edit§ion=25)] This section needs expansion with: the content specified on the talk page. You can help by Vitamin C - specifically, in the form of ascorbate - performs numerous physiological functions in the human body by serving as an [enzyme](/wiki/Enzyme) [substrate](/wiki/Substrate_(biochemistry)) or [cofactor](/wiki/Cofactor_(biochemistry)) and an [electron donor](/wiki/Electron_donor). These functions include the synthesis of [collagen](/wiki/Collagen), [carnitine](/wiki/Carnitine), and [neurotransmitters](/wiki/Neurotransmitter); the synthesis and [catabolism](/wiki/Catabolism) of the metabolism of [microsomes](/wiki/Microsome). [[27]](#cite_note-Gropper_2005-27) During biosynthesis, ascorbate acts as a reducing agent, donating electrons and preventing oxidation to keep iron and copper atoms in their reduced states. Vitamin C functions as a cofactor for the following [enzymes](/wiki/Enzyme): - Three groups of enzymes ( [prolyl-3-hydroxylases](/wiki/Prolyl-3-hydroxylase), [prolyl-4-hydroxylases](/wiki/P4HA1), and hydroxylases](/wiki/Lysyl_hydroxylase)) that are groups](/wiki/Hydroxide)to collagen molecule via [prolyl hydroxylase](/wiki/Prolyl_hydroxylase)and [lysyl hydroxylase](/wiki/Lysyl_hydroxylase), both requiring vitamin C as a [cofactor](/wiki/Cofactor_(biochemistry)). The role of vitamin C as a cofactor is to oxidize prolyl hydroxylase and lysyl hydroxylase from Fe2+ to reduce it from Fe3+ to Fe2+. Hydroxylation allows the collagen molecule to assume its triple [helix](/wiki/Helix)structure, and thus vitamin C is essential to the development and maintenance of [scar tissue](/wiki/Granulation_tissue), [blood necessary for synthesis of c-terminal glycine residues. This increases peptide hormone stability and activity. [[122]](#cite_note-pmid8518727-122) [[123]](#cite_note-pmid1575450-123) Absorption, metabolism and excretion[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C&action=edit§ion=26)] From Institutes of Health: [In humans] "Approximately 70%-90% of vitamin C is absorbed at moderate intakes of 30-180 mg/day. However, at doses above 1,000 mg/day, absorption falls to less than 50%." [[13]](#cite_note-NIH2016-13) It is transported through the intestine via both glucose-sensitive and glucose-insensitive mechanisms, so the presence of large quantities of sugar in the intestine can slow absorption. [[124]](#cite_note-124) Ascorbic acid is absorbed in the body by both active transport and simple diffusion. Sodium-Dependent Active Transport—Sodium-Ascorbate Co-Transporters (SVCTs) and Hexose transporters (GLUTs)—are the two transporter proteins required for active absorption. [SVCT1](/wiki/SLC23A1) and [SVCT2](/wiki/SLC23A2) import the reduced form of ascorbate across plasma membranes. [[125]](#cite_note-Savini_2008-125) [GLUT1](/wiki/GLUT1) and [GLUT3](/wiki/GLUT3) are glucose transporters, and transfer only the dehydroascorbic acid (DHA) form of vitamin C. [[126]](#cite_note-pmid9228080-126) Although dehydroascorbic acid is absorbed in higher rate than ascorbate, the amount of dehydroascorbic acid found in plasma and tissues under normal conditions is low, as cells rapidly reduce dehydroascorbic acid to ascorbate. [[127]](#cite_note-pmid12729925-127) SVCTs appear to be the predominant system for vitamin C transport in the body, [[125]](#cite_note-Savini_2008-125) the notable exception being red blood cells, which lose SVCT proteins during maturation. [[128]](#cite_note-pmid17586466-128) In both vitamin C synthesizers (example: rat) and non-synthesizers (example: human) cells with few exceptions maintain ascorbic acid concentrations much higher than the approximately 50 micromoles/liter (µmol/L) found in plasma. For example, the ascorbic acid content of pituitary and adrenal glands can exceed 2,000 µmol/L, and muscle is at 200-300 µmol/L. [[129]](#cite_note-Padayatty2016-129) The known coenzymatic functions of ascorbic acid do not require such high concentrations, so there may be other, as yet unknown functions. A consequence of all this high concentration organ content is that plasma vitamin C is not a good indicator of whole-body status, and people may vary in the amount of time needed to show symptoms of deficiency when consuming a diet very low in vitamin C. [[129]](#cite_note-Padayatty2016-129) Excretion can be as ascorbic acid, via urine. In humans, during times of low dietary intake, vitamin C is reabsorbed by the kidneys rather than excreted. This salvage process delays onset of deficiency. Only when plasma concentrations are 1.4 mg/dL or higher does re-absorption decline and the excess amounts pass freely into the urine. [[130]](#cite_note-pmid8263270-130) Ascorbic acid also converts (reversibly) to dehydroascorbate (DHA) and from that compound non-reversibly to 2,3-diketogulonate and then oxalate. These three compounds are also excreted via urine. Humans are better than guinea pigs at converting DHA back to ascorbate, and thus take much longer to become vitamin C deficient. [[131]](#cite_note-Linster2007-131) Chemistry[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C&action=edit§ion=27)] The name "vitamin C" always refers to the [l-enantiomer](/wiki/Enantiomer) of ascorbic acid and its [oxidized](/wiki/Redox) forms, such as dehydroascorbate (DHA). Therefore, unless written otherwise, "ascorbate" and "ascorbic acid" refer in the nutritional literature to l-ascorbate and l-ascorbic acid respectively. Ascorbic acid is a [weak](/wiki/Weak_acid) [sugar acid](/wiki/Sugar_acid) structurally related to [glucose](/wiki/Glucose). In biological systems, ascorbic acid can be found only at low [pH](/wiki/PH), but in solutions above pH 5 is predominantly found in the [ionized](/wiki/Ionized) form, ascorbate. All of these molecules have vitamin C activity and thus are used synonymously with vitamin C, unless otherwise specified.[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] Numerous analytical methods have been developed for ascorbic acid detection. For example, vitamin C content of a food sample such as fruit juice can be calculated by measuring the volume of the sample required to decolorize a solution of [dichlorophenolindophenol](/wiki/Dichlorophenolindophenol) (DCPIP) and then calibrating the results by comparison with a known concentration of vitamin C. [[132]](#cite_note-132) [[133]](#cite_note-133) Testing[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C&action=edit§ion=28)] Simple tests are available to measure the levels of vitamin C in [urine](/wiki/Urine) and [serum](/wiki/Serous_fluid). [[29]](#cite_note-Carr2016-29) [[30]](#cite_note-Schleicher2009-30) These better reflect recent dietary intake rather than total body content. [[11]](#cite_note-DRItext-11) It has been observed that while serum concentrations follow a [circadian rhythm](/wiki/Circadian_rhythm) or reflect short-term dietary influence, content within cells or tissues is more stable and can give a better view of the availability of ascorbate within the entire organism. However, very few hospital laboratories are adequately equipped and trained to carry out such detailed analyses. [[134]](#cite_note-134) [[135]](#cite_note-135) Synthesis[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C&action=edit§ion=29)] Most animals and plants are able to synthesize vitamin C through a sequence of [enzyme](/wiki/Enzyme)-driven steps, which convert [monosaccharides](/wiki/Monosaccharides) to vitamin C. Yeasts do not make l-ascorbic acid but rather its [stereoisomer](/wiki/Stereoisomer), [erythorbic acid](/wiki/Erythorbic_acid). [[136]](#cite_note-136) In plants, synthesis is accomplished through the conversion of [mannose](/wiki/Mannose) or [galactose](/wiki/Galactose) to ascorbic acid. [[137]](#cite_note-pmid9620799-137) [[138]](#cite_note-Stone-138) In animals, the starting material is [glucose](/wiki/Glucose). In some species that synthesize ascorbate in the liver (including [mammals](/wiki/Mammal) and [perching birds](/wiki/Passerine)), the glucose is extracted from [glycogen](/wiki/Glycogen); ascorbate synthesis is a glycogenolysis-dependent process. [[139]](#cite_note-pmid11458272-139) In humans and in animals that cannot synthesize vitamin C, the enzyme [l-gulonolactone oxidase](/wiki/Gulonolactone_oxidase) (GULO), which catalyses the last step non-functional. [[140]](#cite_note-valpuesta-140) [[141]](#cite_note-pmid1962571-141) [[142]](#cite_note-pmid1400507-142) synthesis[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C&action=edit§ion=30)] There is some information on serum vitamin C concentrations maintained in animal species that are able to synthesize vitamin C. One study of several breeds of dogs reported an average of 35.9 mol/L. [[144]](#cite_note-144) A report on goats, sheep and cattle reported ranges of 100-110, 265-270 and 160-350 mol/L, respectively. [[145]](#cite_note-Ranjan2012-145) The biosynthesis of ascorbic acid in [vertebrates](/wiki/Vertebrates) starts with the formation of UDP-glucuronic acid. UDP-glucuronic acid is formed when UDP-glucose [UMP](/wiki/Uridine_monophosphate) and [glucuronokinase](/wiki/Glucuronokinase), with the ADP, removes the final phosphate leading to [d-glucuronic acid](/wiki/Glucuronic_acid). The aldehyde group of this compound is reduced to a primary alcohol using the enzyme [glucuronate reductase](/wiki/Glucuronate_reductase) and the cofactor NADPH, yielding hydrolase the enzyme (which see [Unitary the cofactor produces 2-oxogulonolactone (2-keto-gulonolactone), which spontaneously undergoes [enolization](/wiki/Enolization) to form ascorbic acid. [[146]](#cite_note-Seanet-146) [[147]](#cite_note-West_Sussex_2009-147) [[131]](#cite_note-Linster2007-131) Some mammals have lost the ability to synthesize vitamin C, including [simians](/wiki/Simian) and [tarsiers](/wiki/Tarsier), which together make up one of two major [primate](/wiki/Primate) suborders, [Haplorrhini](/wiki/Haplorrhini). This group includes humans. The other more primitive primates ( [Strepsirrhini](/wiki/Strepsirrhini)) have the ability to make vitamin C. Synthesis does not occur in most bats [[140]](#cite_note-valpuesta-140) nor in species in the rodent family [Caviidae](/wiki/Caviidae), which includes [guinea pigs](/wiki/Guinea_pig) and [capybaras](/wiki/Capybara), but does occur in other rodents, including [rats](/wiki/Rat) and [mice](/wiki/Mouse). [[148]](#cite_note-148) [Reptiles](/wiki/Reptile) and older orders of [birds](/wiki/Bird) make ascorbic acid in their kidneys. Recent orders of birds and most mammals make ascorbic acid in their liver. [[138]](#cite_note-Stone-138) A number of species of [passerine](/wiki/Passerine) birds also do not synthesize, but not all of them, and those that do not are not clearly related; it has been proposed that the ability was lost separately a number of times in birds. [[149]](#cite_note-Martinez_del_Rio_1997-149) In particular, the ability to synthesize vitamin C is presumed to have been lost and then later re-acquired in at least two cases. [[150]](#cite_note-pmid22294879-150) The ability to synthesize vitamin C has also been lost in about 96% of [extant](/wiki/Extant_taxon) fish [[151]](#cite_note-Berra-151) (the [teleosts](/wiki/Teleosts)). [[150]](#cite_note-pmid22294879-150) Most tested families of bats (order [Chiroptera](/wiki/Chiroptera)), including major insect and fruit-eating bat families, cannot synthesize vitamin C. A trace of gulonolactone oxidase was detected in only 1 of 34 bat species tested, across the range of 6 families of bats tested. [[152]](#cite_note-152) There are at least two species of bats, frugivorous ( [Rousettus leschenaultii](/wiki/Rousettus_leschenaultii)) and insectivorous bat ( [Hipposideros armiger](/wiki/Hipposideros_armiger)), that retain (or regained) their ability of vitamin C production. [[153]](#cite_note-pmid21037206-153) [[154]](#cite_note-pmid22069493-154) Some of these species (including humans) are able to make do with the lower amounts available from their diets by recycling oxidised vitamin C. [[155]](#cite_note-pmid18358815-155) On a milligram consumed per kilogram of body weight basis, most [simian](/wiki/Simian) species consume the vitamin in amounts 10 to 20 times higher than what is recommended by governments for humans. [[156]](#cite_note-pmid10378206-156) This discrepancy constitutes much of the basis of the controversy on current recommended dietary allowances. It is countered by arguments that humans are very good at conserving dietary vitamin C, and are able to maintain blood levels of vitamin C comparable with simians on a far smaller dietary intake, perhaps by recycling oxidized vitamin C. [[155]](#cite_note-pmid18358815-155) Evolution of animal synthesis[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C&action=edit§ion=31)] Ascorbic acid is a common enzymatic [cofactor](/wiki/Cofactor_(biochemistry)) in mammals used in the synthesis of [collagen](/wiki/Collagen), as well as a powerful [reducing agent](/wiki/Reducing_agent) capable of rapidly scavenging a number of [reactive oxygen species](/wiki/Reactive_oxygen_species) (ROS). Given that ascorbate has these important functions, it is surprising that the ability to synthesize this molecule has not always been conserved. In fact, anthropoid primates, [Cavia porcellus](/wiki/Guinea_pig) (guinea pigs), [teleost](/wiki/Teleost) fishes, most bats, and some [passerine](/wiki/Passerine) birds have all independently lost the ability to internally synthesize vitamin C in either the kidney or the liver. [[157]](#cite_note-157) [[150]](#cite_note-pmid22294879-150) In all of the cases where genomic analysis was done on an ascorbic acid [auxotroph](/wiki/Auxotrophy), the origin of the change was found to be a result of loss-of-function mutations in the gene that encodes L-gulono--lactone oxidase, the enzyme that catalyzes the last step of the ascorbic acid pathway outlined above. [[158]](#cite_note-158) One explanation for the repeated loss of the ability to synthesize vitamin C is that it was the result of [genetic drift](/wiki/Genetic_drift); assuming that the diet was rich in vitamin C, natural selection would not act to preserve it. [[159]](#cite_note-159) [[160]](#cite_note-160) In the case of the simians, it is thought that the loss of the ability to make vitamin C may have occurred much farther back in evolutionary history than the emergence of humans or even apes, since it evidently occurred soon after the appearance of the first primates, yet sometime after the split of early primates into the two major suborders [Haplorrhini](/wiki/Haplorrhini) (which cannot make vitamin C) and its sister suborder of non-tarsier prosimians, the [Strepsirrhini](/wiki/Strepsirrhini) ("wet-nosed" primates), which retained the ability to make vitamin C. [[161]](#cite_note-pmid3113259-161) According to molecular clock dating, these two suborder primate branches parted ways about 63 to 60 million years ago. [[162]](#cite_note-pmid15085543-162) Approximately three to five million years later (58 million years ago), only a short time afterward from an evolutionary perspective, the infraorder [Tarsiiformes](/wiki/Tarsiiformes), whose only remaining family is that of the tarsier ( [Tarsiidae](/wiki/Tarsiidae)), branched off from the other haplorrhines. [[163]](#cite_note-pmid9668008-163) [[164]](#cite_note-Porter_1997-164) Since tarsiers also cannot make vitamin C, this implies the mutation had already occurred, and thus must have occurred between these two marker points (63 to 58 million years ago). [[161]](#cite_note-pmid3113259-161) It has also been noted that the loss of the ability to synthesize ascorbate strikingly parallels the inability to break down [uric acid](/wiki/Uric_acid), also a characteristic of primates. Uric acid and ascorbate are both strong [reducing agents](/wiki/Reducing_agent). This has led to the suggestion that, in higher primates, uric acid has taken over some of the functions of ascorbate. [[165]](#cite_note-pmid5477017-165) Plant synthesis[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C&action=edit§ion=32)] There are many different biosynthesis pathways for ascorbic acid in plants. Most of these pathways are derived from products found in glycolysis and other pathways. For example, one pathway goes through the plant cell wall polymers. [[140]](#cite_note-valpuesta-140) The plant ascorbic acid biosynthesis pathway most principal seems to be l-galactose. l-Galactose reacts with the enzyme l-galactose dehydrogenase, whereby the lactone ring opens and forms again but with lactone between the carbonyl on C1 and hydroxyl produce ascorbic acid. acid has a negative feedback on l-galactose dehydrogenase in spinach. [[167]](#cite_note-167) Ascorbic acid efflux by embryo of dicots plants is a well-established mechanism of iron reduction, and a step obligatory for iron uptake. [[a]](#cite_note-169) All plants synthesize ascorbic acid. Ascorbic acid functions as a cofactor for enzymes involved in photosynthesis, synthesis of plant hormones, as an antioxidant and also regenerator of other antioxidants. [[169]](#cite_note-Gallie2013-170) Plants use multiple pathways to synthesize vitamin C. The major pathway starts with glucose, [fructose](/wiki/Fructose) or [mannose](/wiki/Mannose) (all simple sugars) and proceeds to L- [galactose](/wiki/Galactose), L-galactonolactone and ascorbic acid. [[169]](#cite_note-Gallie2013-170) [[170]](#cite_note-Mellidou2017-171) There is feedback regulation in place, in that the presence of ascorbic acid inhibits enzymes in the synthesis pathway. [[171]](#cite_note-172) This process follows a [diurnal rhythm](/wiki/Diurnal_rhythm), so that enzyme expression peaks in the morning to support biosynthesis later on when mid-day sunlight intensity demands high ascorbic acid concentrations. [[170]](#cite_note-Mellidou2017-171) Minor pathways may be specific to certain parts of plants; these can be either identical to the vertebrate pathway (including the GLO enzyme), or start with inositol and get to ascorbic acid via L-galactonic acid to L-galactonolactone. [[169]](#cite_note-Gallie2013-170) Industrial synthesis[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C&action=edit§ion=33)] Vitamin C is produced from [glucose](/wiki/Glucose) by two main routes. The [Reichstein process](/wiki/Reichstein_process), developed in the 1930s, uses a single pre-fermentation followed by a purely chemical route. The modern two-step [fermentation](/wiki/Fermentation_(biochemistry)) process, originally developed in [China](/wiki/China) in the 1960s, uses additional fermentation to replace part of the later chemical stages. The Reichstein process and the modern two-step fermentation processes use [sorbitol](/wiki/Sorbitol) as the starting material and convert it to [sorbose](/wiki/Sorbose) using fermentation. [[172]](#cite_note-173) The modern two-step fermentation process then converts sorbose to 2-keto-l-gulonic acid (KGA) through another fermentation step, avoiding an extra intermediate. Both processes yield approximately 60% vitamin C from the glucose feed. [[173]](#cite_note-174) In 2017, China produced about 95% of the world supply of ascorbic acid (vitamin C), [[174]](#cite_note-fbn-175) which is China's most exported vitamin, having total revenue of US$880 million in 2017. [[175]](#cite_note-koe-176) Due to pressure on Chinese industry to discontinue burning [coal](/wiki/Coal) normally used for vitamin C manufacturing, the price of vitamin C rose three-fold in 2016 alone to US$12 per kg. of [Vasco da Gama](/wiki/Vasco_da_Gama), the curative effects of citrus fruit were known. [[176]](#cite_note-177) [[177]](#cite_note-178) Later, the Portuguese planted fruit trees and vegetables in [Saint Helena](/wiki/Saint_Helena), a stopping point for homebound voyages from Asia, which sustained passing ships. [[178]](#cite_note-179) Authorities occasionally recommended plant food to prevent scurvy during long sea voyages. [John Woodall](/wiki/John_Woodall), the first surgeon to the [British East India Company](/wiki/British_East_India_Company), recommended the preventive and curative use of [lemon](/wiki/Lemon) juice in his 1617 book, The Surgeon's Mate. [[179]](#cite_note-180) In 1734, the [Dutch](/wiki/Netherlands) writer [Johann Bachstrom](/wiki/Johann_Bachstrom) gave the firm opinion, "scurvy is solely owing to a total abstinence from fresh vegetable food, and greens." [[180]](#cite_note-181) [[181]](#cite_note-182) Scurvy had long been a principal killer of sailors during the long sea voyages. [[182]](#cite_note-url_BBC_Captain_Cook_Scurvy-183) According to Jonathan Lamb, "In 1499, Vasco da Gama lost 116 of his crew of 170; In 1520, Magellan lost 208 out of 230;...all mainly to scurvy." [[183]](#cite_note-184) The first attempt to give scientific basis for the cause of this disease was by a ship's surgeon in the [Royal Navy](/wiki/Royal_Navy), [James Lind](/wiki/James_Lind). While at sea in May 1747, Lind provided some crew members with two oranges and one lemon per day, in addition to normal rations, while others continued on [cider](/wiki/Cider), [vinegar](/wiki/Vinegar), [sulfuric acid](/wiki/Sulfuric_acid) or [seawater](/wiki/Seawater), along with their normal rations, in one of the world's first controlled experiments. [[37]](#cite_note-Baron2009-37) The results showed that citrus fruits prevented the disease. Lind published his work in 1753 in his Treatise on the Scurvy. [[38]](#cite_note-lind_james-38) [[184]](#cite_note-Singh2008-185) Fresh fruit was expensive to keep on board, whereas boiling it down to juice allowed easy storage but destroyed the vitamin (especially if boiled in copper kettles). [[103]](#cite_note-Oxford-103) It was 1796 before the British navy adopted [lemon](/wiki/Lemon) juice as standard issue at sea. In 1845, ships in the West Indies were provided with [lime](/wiki/Lime_(fruit)) juice instead, and in 1860 lime juice was used throughout the Royal Navy, giving rise to the American use of the nickname ["limey"](/wiki/Alternative_words_for_British) for the British. [[37]](#cite_note-Baron2009-37) [Captain James Cook](/wiki/James_Cook) had previously demonstrated the advantages of carrying ["Sour krout"](/wiki/Sauerkraut) on board, by taking his crews to the [Hawaiian Islands](/wiki/Hawaiian_Islands) without losing any of his men to scurvy. [[185]](#cite_note-isbn0-14-043647-2-186) For this, the British Admiralty awarded him a medal. The name antiscorbutic was used in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries for foods known to prevent scurvy. These foods included lemons, limes, oranges, sauerkraut, cabbage, [malt](/wiki/Malt), and [portable soup](/wiki/Portable_soup). [[186]](#cite_note-isbn1-74114-200-8-187) In 1928, the Canadian Arctic anthropologist [Vilhjalmur Stefansson](/wiki/Vilhjalmur_Stefansson) showed that the [Inuit](/wiki/Inuit) avoid scurvy on a diet of largely raw meat. Later studies on traditional food diets of the [Yukon](/wiki/Yukon) [First Nations](/wiki/First_Nations_in_Canada), [Dene](/wiki/Dene_people), [Inuit](/wiki/Inuit), and [Métis](/wiki/M%C3%A9tis_(Canada)) of Northern Canada showed that their daily intake of vitamin C averaged between 52 and 62 mg/day, [[187]](#cite_note-pmid15173410-188) comparable with the [Estimated Average Requirement](/wiki/Estimated_Average_Requirement). [[11]](#cite_note-DRItext-11) Discovery[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C&action=edit§ion=36)] Vitamin C was discovered in 1912, isolated in 1928 and synthesized in 1933, making it the first vitamin to be synthesized. [[18]](#cite_note-Squires-18) Shortly thereafter [Tadeus Reichstein](/wiki/Tadeus_Reichstein) succeeded in synthesizing the vitamin in bulk by what is now called the [Reichstein process](/wiki/Reichstein_process). [[189]](#cite_note-pmid356548-190) This made possible the inexpensive mass-production of vitamin C. In 1934 [Hoffmann-La Roche](/wiki/Hoffmann%E2%80%93La_Roche) trademarked synthetic vitamin C under the brand name [Redoxon](/wiki/Redoxon) [[190]](#cite_note-Roche1934-191) and began to market it as a dietary supplement. [[b]](#cite_note-193) In 1907 a laboratory animal model which would help to identify the antiscorbutic factor was discovered by the Norwegian physicians [Axel Holst](/wiki/Axel_Holst) and [Theodor Frølich](/wiki/Theodor_Fr%C3%B8lich), who when studying shipboard [beriberi](/wiki/Beriberi), fed [guinea pigs](/wiki/Guinea_pig) their test diet of grains and flour and were surprised when scurvy resulted instead of beriberi. By luck, this species did not make its own vitamin C, whereas mice and rats do. [[192]](#cite_note-pmid12555613-194) In 1912, the [Polish](/wiki/Poland) biochemist [Casimir Funk](/wiki/Casimir_Funk) developed the concept of [vitamins](/wiki/Vitamin). One of these was thought to be the anti-scorbutic factor. In 1928, this was referred to as "water-soluble C", although its chemical structure had not been determined. [[193]](#cite_note-pmid9105273-195) From 1928 to 1932, [Albert Szent-Györgyi](/wiki/Albert_Szent-Gy%C3%B6rgyi) and Joseph L. Svirbely's Hungarian team, and [Charles Glen King](/wiki/Charles_Glen_King)'s American team, identified the anti-scorbutic factor. Szent-Györgyi isolated hexuronic acid from animal adrenal glands, and suspected it to be the antiscorbutic factor. [[194]](#cite_note-pmid16744896-196) In late 1931, Szent-Györgyi gave Svirbely the last of his adrenal-derived hexuronic acid with the suggestion that it might be the anti-scorbutic factor. By the spring of 1932, King's laboratory had proven this, but published the result without giving Szent-Györgyi credit for it. This led to a bitter dispute over priority. [[194]](#cite_note-pmid16744896-196) In 1933, [Walter Norman Haworth](/wiki/Walter_Norman_Haworth) chemically identified the vitamin as l-hexuronic acid, proving this by synthesis in 1933. [[195]](#cite_note-pmid11963399-197) [[196]](#cite_note-pmid4589872-198) [[197]](#cite_note-pmid4612454-199) [[198]](#cite_note-url_NLM_Profiles_Szent-Gyorgyi-200) Haworth and Szent-Györgyi proposed be named a-scorbic acid, and chemically l-ascorbic acid, in honor of its activity against scurvy. [[198]](#cite_note-url_NLM_Profiles_Szent-Gyorgyi-200) [[18]](#cite_note-Squires-18) The term's etymology is from Latin, "a-" meaning away, or off from, while -scorbic is from Medieval Latin scorbuticus (pertaining to scurvy), cognate with Old Norse Dutch scheurbuik Low German scharbock. [[199]](#cite_note-201) Partly for this discovery, Szent-Györgyi was awarded the 1937 [Nobel Prize in Medicine](/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physiology_or_Medicine), [[200]](#cite_note-202) and [Haworth](/wiki/Norman_Haworth) shared that year's [Nobel Prize in Chemistry](/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Chemistry). [[23]](#cite_note-Zet2009-23) In 1957, J. J. Burns showed that some mammals are susceptible to scurvy as their [liver](/wiki/Liver) does not produce the [enzyme](/wiki/Enzyme) [l-gulonolactone oxidase](/wiki/L-gulonolactone_oxidase), the last of the chain of four enzymes that synthesize vitamin C. [[201]](#cite_note-pmid13385237-203) [[202]](#cite_note-pmid13380431-204) American biochemist [Irwin Stone](/wiki/Irwin_Stone) was the first to exploit vitamin C for its food preservative properties. He later developed the idea that humans possess a mutated form of the l-gulonolactone oxidase coding gene. [[203]](#cite_note-pmid1672383-205) In 2008, researchers at the [University of Montpellier](/wiki/University_of_Montpellier) discovered that in humans and other primates the [red blood cells](/wiki/Red_blood_cell) have evolved a mechanism to more efficiently utilize the vitamin C present in the body by recycling oxidized l-dehydroascorbic acid (DHA) back into ascorbic acid for reuse by the body. The mechanism was not found to be present in mammals that synthesize their own vitamin C. [[155]](#cite_note-pmid18358815-155) Large doses[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C&action=edit§ion=37)] Vitamin C megadosage is a term describing the consumption or injection of vitamin C in doses comparable to or higher than the amounts produced by the livers of mammals which are able to synthesize vitamin C. An argument for this, although not the actual term, was described in 1970 in an article by [Linus Pauling](/wiki/Linus_Pauling). Briefly, his position was that for optimal health, humans should be consuming at least 2,300 mg/day to compensate for the inability to synthesize vitamin C. The recommendation also fell into the consumption range for gorillas - a non-synthesizing near-relative to humans. [[204]](#cite_note-pmid5275366-206) A second argument for high intake is that serum ascorbic acid concentrations increase as intake increases until it plateaus at about 190 to 200 micromoles per liter (µmol/L) once consumption exceeds 1,250 milligrams. [[205]](#cite_note-Mandl2009-207) As noted, government recommendations are a range of 40 to 110 mg/day and normal plasma is approximately 50 µmol/L, so 'normal' is about 25% of what can be achieved when oral consumption is in the proposed megadose range. Pauling popularized the concept of high dose vitamin C as prevention and treatment of the common cold in 1970. A few years later he proposed that vitamin C would prevent cardiovascular disease, and that 10 grams/day, initially (10 days) administered intravenously and thereafter orally, would cure late-stage cancer. [[206]](#cite_note-208) Mega-dosing with ascorbic acid has other champions, among them chemist [Irwin Stone](/wiki/Irwin_Stone) and the controversial [Matthias Rath](/wiki/Matthias_Rath) and [Patrick Holford](/wiki/Patrick_Holford), who both have been accused of making unsubstantiated treatment claims for treating cancer and [HIV](/wiki/HIV) infection.[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] Vitamin C mega-dosages are to a large degree discredited. There is no scientific evidence that vitamin C megadosage helps to cure or prevent cancer, the common cold, or some other medical conditions. [[207]](#cite_note-ACS-209) [[208]](#cite_note-:0-210) Benefits are not superior when supplement intakes of more than 1,000 mg/day are compared to intakes between 200 and 1,000 mg/day, and so not limited to the mega-dose range. [[209]](#cite_note-LPI-211) [[210]](#cite_note-Hemila2009-212) The idea that large amounts of intravenous ascorbic acid can be used to treat late-stage cancer is - some forty years after Pauling's seminal paper - still considered unproven and still in need of high quality research. [[211]](#cite_note-Wil2014-213) [[56]](#cite_note-Jacobs2015-56) However, a lack of evidence has not stopped individual physicians from prescribing intravenous ascorbic acid to thousands of people with cancer. [[56]](#cite_note-Jacobs2015-56) Society and culture[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C&action=edit§ion=38)] In February 2011, the [Swiss Post](/wiki/Swiss_Post) issued a postage stamp bearing a depiction of a model of a molecule of vitamin C to mark the [International Year of Chemistry](/wiki/International_Year_of_Chemistry). [[212]](#cite_note-swissinfo-214) Brand names[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_C&action=edit§ion=39)] Vitamin C is sold around the world as a stand-alone product at amounts up to 1,000 mg and as part of [fixed-dose combination](/wiki/Fixed-dose_combination) products, under many brand names. [^](#cite_ref-169)Dicot plants transport if the iron circulates as [ferric](/wiki/Ferric)complexes (Fe3+), it has to undergo a reduction before it can be actively transported. Plant embryos efflux high amounts of ascorbate that chemically reduce iron(III) from ferric complexes.
